bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States For the Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Amended Application for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for Gwoo Shee Ah Look. | 2649
To the Hon. Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of said Court:

Your petitioner respectfully shows to the Court that Gwoo Shee Ah Look, who has been termed, Ah. Sing, Alias Gwoo Shee, alias Gwoo Ah Look, by the United States Immigration authorities, is a Chinese woman born in China, but has been domiciled and has been an actual bona fide resident of the United States for a number of years; that said Gwoo Shee Ah Look has been ordered deported from the United States to China by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor of the United States, and that said Secretary of Commerce and Labor has issued his warrant directed to R.P. Bonham, Acting Inspector of Immigration Services at Portland, Oregon, for the deportation of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look from the United States to China;

Pursuant to said writ and order of deportation your petitioner further shows that in the month of January, 1914, the said R.P. Bonham, as such Acting Inspector of Immigration Service at Portland, Oregon, to the City of Seattle, State of Washington, where she was delievered to the Immigration authorities at that time and there detained in the Immigration House of Detention pursuant to said writ and order of deportation; that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look was unlawfully restrained, imprisoned and detained of her liberty by the said R.P. Bonham, Acting Immigration Inspector of Portland,
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -1-
Oregon, byt the Immigration authorities of the United States at Seattle, Washington in the said House of Detention; that the said R.P. Bonham clandestinely, secretly, and without authority of law removed the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look from the County Jail of the County of Multnomah, State of Oregon, and clandestinely and secretly detained her and has refused upon the application of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look, as well as that of her husband, Wong Sing Lung, to let it be known where she was detained, but on the contrary her location and whereabouts was ascertained through the efforts of the said Wong Sing Lung at Seattle, Washington.

Your petitioner further shows that after ascertaining the whereabouts of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look, to-wit, in the Immigration House of Detention in Seattle, Washington, tht he for and on behalf of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look filed a petition in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division, praying for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and that such proceedings and action was had upon upon said petition, that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look is now being detained at said House of Detention of said Immigration authorities upon a Writ issued pursuant to the said petition for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, requiring the official having said Gwoo Shee Ah Look in charge and custody to appear and show cause why a Writ of Habeas Corpus should not issue.

Your petitioner shows that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look arrived in the United States at the City of San Francisco on the Steamer "Siberia", during the year 1907, the exact date of which is unknown to your petitioner, since which time she has been continuously domiciled within the United States, and your petitioner further shows that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look is unlawfully imprisioned, detained and confined and restrained of her liberty by the Immigration authorities of the United States at the Immigration House of Dentention
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -2-
in the City of Seattle, Washington, as aforesaid.

Your petitioner further shows that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look came to the State of Oregon from the State of California during the early part of October, 1913, and that shortly after her arrival in said City she was arrested and charged by the Immigration authorities under a provisions of a statute of the United States with being unlawfully within the United States, in that since her arrival and domicile within the United States she had been found practicing prostitution and that she was a prostitute.

Your petitioner further shows that the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look was arrested by the police officers in the City of Portland on the 4th day of November, 1913, in a certain raid conducted by the police officers and thereafter turned over to the Inspector of Immigration J.H. Barbour, who on the 5th day of November, 1913, at the Police Station conducted an investigation and examination of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look secretly and without allowing the presence of any person at the time of the taking of such statements, and that thereafter the said J.H. Barbour caused the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look to be imprisioned and confined in the County Jail of the County of Mulnomah, State of Oregon, upon the said charge; that thereafter the said J.H. Barbour caused a further examination to be made and had Gwoo Shee Ah Look brought before his and her statements were taken by the said J.H. Barbour relative to the charge which had theretofore been placed against her, to-wit, of being unlawfully within the United States, in that she had been found practicing prostitution while domiciled therein and that she was a prostitute.

Your petitioner further shows that thereafter the said J.H. Barbour caused the testimony of L.A. Harms and J.M. Wise, two police officers, to be taken in his office and that said two witnesses testified relative to the said charge against the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look; that the said testimony of the said L.A. Harms and J.M. Wise was conducted secretly without the presence of the said
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -3-
Gwoo Shee Ah Look and without the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look being allowed the privilege of having an attorney or ccounsel present to examine and cross-examine said witnesses, likewise Gwoo Shee Ah Look was unable to have counsel present at the time she was examined by the said J.H. Barbour, and that the said manner of conducting said examination of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look and said L.A. Harms and J.M. Wise was in violation of Rule 22 of the Department of Commerce and Labor, Clause B of Sub-division 4, which provides:

"During the course of the hearings the alien shall be allowed to inspect the warrant of arrest and all the evidence on which it was issued; and at such stage thereof as the officer before whom the hearing is held shall deem proper, he shall be apprised that he may thereafter be represented by counsel and shall be required then and there to state whether he desires counsel or waives the same, and his reply shall be entered on the record. If counsel be selected, he shall be permitted to be present during the further conduct of the hearing, to inspect and make a copy of minutes of the hearing, so far as it has proceeded, and to offer evidence to meet any evidence theretofore or thereafter presented by the government. Objections and exceptions of counsel shall not be entered on the record, but may be dealt with in an accompanying brief."

That said Gwoo Shee Ah Look does not speak the English language and that all communication with her was had through an interpreter, and that she is ignorant in the ways of the world and protection of her rights, and that when her examination as well as that of the other witnesses was being conducted she did not understand her rights or understand the dangers which she was encountering wihout having counsel present to conduct the examination in her behalf and look after her rights.

Your petitioner further shows that the second day after the arrest of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look and before the said J.H. Barbour as such Inspector of Immigration had conducted his second examination of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look and before he had conducted his examination of the said L.A. Harms and J.M. Wise that he employed the law firm of Wilbur & Spencer and A. L. Clark of the City of Portland, Oregon, to represent and look after the interests
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -4-
of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look; that at said time the said J.H. Barbour, Inspector of Immigration Office at Portland, Oregon, conferred with the said A.L. Clark who requested of the said J.H. Barbour permission to visit the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look, who was then confined in the County Jail, and that at said time the said Barbour was informed that said persons represented the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look; that the said J.H. Barbour thereupon refused counsel so requesting permission the right or privilege at that time to see or consult with the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look; that thereafter on several occasions and before the examination of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look and other witnesses had been completed the said A.L. Clark requested of said J.H. Barbour that he be notified when said hearing was conducted and requested the privilege of being present at such examination and cross-examination of the witnesses, which request was regused and although having promised so to do the said J.H. Barbour failed and neglected to notify the attorneys for said Gwoo Shee Ah Look of the time and place of conducting such examination; that thereafter after the said examination had been made of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Loo by J.H. Barbour and the testimony reduced to writing on the 19th day of November, 1913, the said J.H. Barbour delivered a transcript of the testimony taken in said manner to the attorneys of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look with the suggestion that such evidence could then be presented by way of affidavit as was deemed proper, and that there was no opportunity given or granted to the said attorneys for Gwoo Shee Ah Look, who were known to be the attorneys for the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look, to be present at any of said examinations conducted to cross-examine any of the witnesses, whose testimony was being taken; that thereafter the said attorneys for the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look procured such affidavits as they were able to procure and filed the same with the said J.H. Barbour, who thereafter transmitted the same with his record to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, who has order the said Gwoo
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -5-
Shee Ah Look's deportation to China and found that the said alien is a prostitute and has been found practicing prostitution subsequent to her entry into the United States.

Your petitioner further alleges that the said order of deportation and the said imprisionment and restraint of the liberty of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look is unlawful and illegal, in that said Gwoo Shee Ah Look was not granted the rights and privileges insured to her in the manner in which the said hearings and testimony were taken by the said J.H. Barbour, Inspector of Immigration, because she was not granted the privilege of having her attorneys present at such examination.

Yor petitioner further alleges that said restraint and order of deportation are illegal in that there was no evidence before the Commissioner or Secretary of Commerce and Labor authorizing the order for said Gwoo Shee Ah Look's deportation. The only evidence before either the Commissioner or the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, save and except the statement of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look which the said parties had before then, was so far as the virtue of Gwoo Shee Ah Look is concerned as follows:
"Q When and where did you first see this woman? (Gwoo Shee Ah Look)
"A About three weeks ago, about two weeks before her arrest was made, upstairs, second floor, in a building on the southwest corner of Fourth and Flanders Streets, this City.
"Q Under what circumstances did you see her at that time?

"A We were investigating that place, knowing that there were Chinese prostitutes up there, about two or three weeks before the arrest was made; we were up there three or four times; Officer Wise and myself.
"Q State briefly what you saw on the occasion of these two investigations, so far as your observation is limited to this woman.

"A in the first plce, we had information from different sources
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -6-
that there were Chinese prostitutes up there. We watched the place on several different occasions and saw Chinese going up there in the rooms that the women were in. We went up there and talked to the women the best we could. At different times we found different men in this woman's room. Finally, about 4:30 in the morning November 4th, we went up with the purpose of making her arrest and we found a Chinese in bed with her.

"Q In your capacity, experience, and observation as a police officer in the Chinese quarter on North Fourth Street, Portland, what have you found to be the reputation of the place out of which this woman was arrested?
"A It has the reputation of being a bawdyhouse where prostitutes ply their trade."
And the testimony of J.M. Wise, who is a police officer of the City of Portland, whose testimony, so far as the virtue of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look is concerned, is substantially as follows:
"Q When, where, and under what circumstances did you first see or meet this woman? (Gwoo Shee Ah Look)
"A Along about the 20th of October, this year, in room 17 of a building on the southwest corner of Fourth and Flanders Street, this City." (Portland)
"Q Under what circumstances did you first see her?
"A Investigating the place, gaining evidence as to this place being a house of prostitution and as to this woman being a prositute.
"Q Did you arrest this woman?
"A Yes, on the 4th day of November, about 4:30 in the morning."
That there was no other testimony relative to the character or acts or prostitution of the said Gwoo Shee Ah Look.
Your petitioner further shows that she said Gwoo Shee Ah Look is not a prostitute and that she has not practiced prostitution within the United States or at any other place.

Your petitoner further shows that the evidence before the said commissioner and the secretary of Commerce and Labor showed in substance that Gwoo Shee Ah Look came to the State of Oregon on the 8th day of October, 1913, when said Gwoo Shee Ah Look went to live with a respectable Chinese family, where she remained until the first day of November, 1913, at which time, she, together with her husband, rented a room at the place where said Gwoo Shee Ah Lok was arrested.

Your petitioner further above that the affidavits in behalf of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look showed in substance that she had not been in the room or at the place where she was arrested until the first day of November, 1913, when she moved there with her husband.

Your petitioner further shows that the facts as above detailed were showsn in the affidavits of Wong Sing Lung, Sue Key Line, Wong Shee, Wong Ark, D.L. Huston and Wlater Bartholemew, all of which were filed with the Commissioner in the City of Portland, attached to the record, and before the said Secretary of Commerce and Labor.

Your petitioner further shows that the sole and only testimony upon which the said Secretary of Commerce and Labor has ordered the deportation of said Gwoo Shee Ah Look was the testimony of said two policemen, the substance of which has been set out herein, and that their testimony that they saw her at the place of her arrest prior to the first day of November, 1913., is untrue and case of mistaken
Wilbur & Spencer Attorneys-At-Law Portland Oregon -8-
identity.
